entry.title: Field Selection for RFQ Document (Ext. Sourcing Req.) - S4Hana Public Cloud
entry.content:
Hi!

My client has a requirement -

They want to make certain fields as Mandatory / Optional when creating a RFQ document for external sourcing.

The reason behind this requirement is that Ext. Sourcing will be carried out by Ariba Team and We as S4Hana users are not concerned about the Mandatory Fields (*). Therefore they want to make certain fields like Quotation Deadline date / company code/ purchase org as optional in the RFQ document. Similarly Target Value / Material / Delivery Address should be marked as Mandatory

 

I have been through Implementation Actives but found no such options to do the customization. 

 

Is there any way to do that? Or do i need to raise this concern to SAP

 

Kindly Guide

entry.title: Data entity with the same name already exists
entry.content:
Scenario having multiple Data Entities named the same from different DB.  It is not possible to add an Data entity with the same name. F.e.
Project A tables:
- MainATable
- DocumentHistory
- Attachments

Project B tables:
- MainBTable
- DocumentHistory
- Attachments

This will lead you into the problem that you only can add one DocumentHistory and one Attachments table at the same time, nevertheless they don't belong together.

Instead of adding them in the background as ProjectA.DocumentHistory and ProjectB.DocumentHistory - the more I work with it, the more I get frustrated!

entry.title: Request for Guidance on Integrating SAP HANA On-Premise Database with SAP Cloud ALM
entry.content:
Dear SAP Support,

I am reaching out to request your assistance in understanding the process for integrating an SAP HANA On-Premise database with SAP Cloud ALM.
We would like to monitor and manage our on-premise HANA system using Cloud ALM, but we are currently unsure about the necessary steps, prerequisites, and configuration required to achieve this.

Could you kindly provide guidance or documentation on how to proceed with this integration?

Thanks.


------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Learn more about the SAP Support user and program here.

entry.title: Re: Request for Guidance on Integrating SAP HANA On-Premi...
entry.content:
Hi Andrea,

Dear customer,

Thank you for contacting SAP Support.

Regarding your specific requirement, SAP CALM can indeed connect to HANA databases to retrieve information. 
However, this functionality is limited to HANA databases running in a cloud environment, such as SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition or SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition.  
You can refer to 'Setup Managed Components (Services & Systems)' to see the products which CALM can be connected. 

Best regards,
SAP Support

entry.title: Re: Understanding the Belgium B2B e-Invoicing Mandate and the Plant Abroad Scenario
entry.content:
Hello @naveen_kolli , 

I have another question about the blog.
Our specific case is as follows: There is a common company code for ‚ÄúBenelux‚Äù (T001-LAND1 = ‚ÄòNL‚Äô). Transactions for the Netherlands and Belgium are processed via this company code. In T001N, there is an entry for this company code with STCEG = ‚ÄúBE***...‚Äù.
Which SAP DRC country process should be used? The result should be e-invoices for the Netherlands (currently not mandatory) and for Belgium (mandatory from January 1, 2026). As I understand it, these are different processes in SAP DRC ‚Äì is that correct? Is there a best practice for customizing here? Can I assign multiple DRC processes to a company code, or is it the ‚ÄúEU_INV‚Äù process that applies to both countries?
Perhaps you can help me with this.
Many thanks and best regards!


Christian Hummel

entry.content: On public cloud, both UPA and 3F0 are default scope item, which means you will always get both of them by default. They are always running together.

entry.title: ü™ê Comet Browser for SAP Users: Practical Browser Automation for Fiori, SuccessFactors & Beyond
entry.content:
TL;DR

Perplexity‚Äôs new Comet browser turns everyday SAP web work (Fiori apps, SuccessFactors, BTP cockpit, Ariba, etc.) into prompt-driven automations. Think: ‚Äúopen My Inbox, filter purchase orders > ‚Ç¨10k awaiting approval, export to CSV, and email me the summary.‚Äù It‚Äôs fast to try, fits neatly alongside your SAP landscape, and, used with the right guardrails, can save hours of repetitive clicks each week.


Free month of Perplexity Pro (referral)
If you want to trial Pro features while evaluating Comet for SAP workflows, use this link:
https://pplx.ai/noptus


Who is this for? ü§∑‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è

  • Fiori power users who triage tasks in My Inbox, Manage Purchase Orders, Manage Sales Orders, or Monitor Stock daily.

  • HR operations teams working in SuccessFactors (for example, bulk checks, report exports, onboarding lists).

  • BTP administrators navigating the SAP BTP Cockpit, toggling service instances, roles, and destinations.

  • Procurement and finance teams using Ariba and S/4HANA web apps that require routine filters, exports, and cross-checks.

 

Why Comet helps SAP users ü™ê

  1. Prompt to action: Ask Comet to perform structured browser tasks across tabs (navigate, search, filter, export, summarize). This acts like a ‚Äúuniversal assistant‚Äù for your SAP web apps: especially helpful when hopping between Fiori tiles, SuccessFactors modules, and admin consoles.

  2. Research and context: Need policy reminders, note formats, or KPI definitions while inside the app? Comet augments pages with in-place explanations and follow-ups without losing context.

  3. Collections and cleanup: Group related SAP tabs (for example, period-end close) and let Comet tidy dormant tabs automatically.

  4. Familiar browsing: Built on Chromium, so everyday browsing patterns feel familiar and enterprise web apps behave as expected.

  5. Availability: Comet is broadly available with free and paid options; check Perplexity for current details.

Five high-impact automation recipes (SAP-ready) ‚úÖ

Use non-production systems first. Validate each step. Keep approvals human-in-the-loop.

  1. Fiori mass triage (My Inbox)
    ‚ÄúOpen My Inbox > filter by ‚ÄòOverdue‚Äô and ‚ÄòAmount > ‚Ç¨10,000‚Äô > group by Company Code > export summary to CSV > draft an email with top 10 items and due dates.‚Äù
    Value: reduces tab gymnastics and produces a tidy escalation brief in minutes.

  2. SuccessFactors onboarding checks
    ‚ÄúOpen SuccessFactors > People Analytics > run ‚ÄòNew Hires last 7 days‚Äô > flag records missing manager or start date > export and summarize blockers.‚Äù
    Value: HR receives a daily exception list instead of a raw dump.

  3. Fiori spend variance pulse
    ‚ÄúOpen Manage Purchase Orders > filter current month > variance > 5% vs contract > list top 20 by supplier; open each PO in a new tab; capture Notes; compile a one-page brief.‚Äù
    Value: pre-curated review pack for controllers.

  4. BTP cockpit housekeeping
    ‚ÄúOpen BTP Cockpit > subaccount X > list service instances with Warning or Error state > fetch last 20 logs per instance > summarize common failures and suggest likely fixes (quota, bindings, plan).‚Äù
    Value: faster incident triage for platform teams.

  5. Ariba price drift watch
    ‚ÄúAriba > reports > compare last quarter unit prices vs catalog; surface items with > 8% drift; generate CSV and bullet summary with supplier names.‚Äù
    Value: quick input for sourcing discussions.

Prompts you can copy-paste üìë

  • ‚ÄúOpen Fiori My Inbox in S/4HANA and filter to ‚ÄòHigh Priority‚Äô + ‚ÄòOverdue‚Äô. For each item, open details in a background tab, extract Vendor, Amount, Requested Delivery, and Approver Chain. Build a table and export it.‚Äù

  • ‚ÄúIn SuccessFactors, pull Headcount by Department for the last 30 days, highlight departures, and list missing exit interviews. Draft a note to the HRBP with the topline and attach the CSV.‚Äù

  • ‚ÄúGo to BTP Cockpit ‚Üí Subaccount X ‚Üí Security ‚Üí Role Collections. Snapshot role assignments changed in the last 48 hours and summarize who gained admin-like rights.‚Äù

Fit with SAP testing and governance üßë‚Äç‚öñÔ∏è

  • Do not replace UI tests: For deterministic app testing, continue using QUnit/OPA5 and your CI/CD pipeline. Comet is an operations assistant, not a test harness.

  • Least privilege: Use read-only roles whenever possible for reporting workflows; elevate only when human approvals are part of the flow.

  • SSO and audit: Run via corporate SSO, keep browser logs, and retain human approval steps for sensitive actions.

A word on security üîê

Independent write-ups and audits have highlighted security considerations around AI-driven browsers, especially where the agent can act on web content. Best practices:

  • Disable auto-actions on untrusted sites.

  • Limit sensitive scopes (banking, payroll, personally identifiable information).

  • Pilot in sandboxes before production.
    Make an informed choice with your security team.

Getting started in 10 minutes ‚è∞

  1. Install Comet and sign in with your Perplexity account.

  2. Create a ‚ÄúSAP Ops‚Äù collection (Fiori launchpad, SuccessFactors Admin Center, BTP Cockpit, Ariba).

  3. Try one recipe above on a development tenant.

  4. Review outputs (CSV, summaries, emails) before sending.

  5. Iterate prompts: add filters, sort keys, and exception rules.

What good looks like üëç

  • Under five minutes from prompt to a usable report.

  • Human review before any approval or posting step.

  • SSO, least-privilege roles, and an audit trail retained.

  • Repeatable prompts saved to a shared team collection.

 

Final thoughts

Comet will not replace your SAP skills; it amplifies them.

Start with simple browser flows you repeat daily, keep humans in the loop, and let the assistant handle the clicks while you focus on decisions. If your team already lives in Fiori and SuccessFactors, this is one of the lowest-friction AI wins you can pilot this quarter.

For long-term fit (policies, data residency, enterprise controls), involve your security and platform teams early and evaluate Comet alongside your existing SAP governance and testing practices.

entry.title: Consumption Indicator
entry.content:
Hi, 

 

In  Learning Journeys / Exploring Production Planning in SAP S/4HANA / Outlining Make-to-Stock Production

Part 

Consumption Indicator

In addition to the consumption mode and consumption periods, the consumption indicator (consumption type) is important. For example, the consumption indicator controls whether the planned independent requirements are consumed with the customer requirements or with dependent requirements and order reservations. It is defined as a default value for each planned independent requirement class in Customizing for Demand Management. You can override the indicator on the item detail screen for planned independent requirements management.

 

What do you mean with : you can override the indicator on the item detail screen for planned independent requirements management. What is ITEM DETAIL SCREEN?   What transaction code is this? 

Thanks

entry.title: Re: Can we use 3F0 (Event-Based Manufacturing Cost Postin...
entry.content:
Dear,

the relationship between 3F0 and UPA is same for many other scope items such as overhead accounting, asset accounting, actual costing etc. please see the blog about UPA Universal Parallel Accounting in SAP S/4HANA - SAP Community

Since UPA is inherently part of public cloud accounting architecture, so it is not possible to separate any accounting scope items from UPA,  and that includes scope item 3F0.

I'm curious why 3F0 is being singled out there, and why there are these questions in the first place.

if there are additional 3F0 questions, feel free to let me know.

Regards,

Sen

entry.title: Re: Cross-Company Code Cost Allocation and Cost Center Tr...
entry.content:
Dear byd,

Thank you for your questions which I will try to answer below and also provide some general feedback / considerations:

Cost allocations in SAP Cloud ERP (S/4HANA Public Cloud) are by default enabled between different company codes (within one system and Controlling Area). The supported Apps are mentioned in sap help which also refers to required configurations (e.g.  Define Intercompany Clearing Accounts, Define Intercompany Margin Accounts, ...).

As all such postings are Management Accounting related (and thus e.g. posted w/o tax) the compliant reflection of such exchanged services under tax transfer pricing and local stat accounting requirements need to be considered. 
SAP offers the solution Intercompany Billing of Cross Company Cost Allocations (Scope Item 4AN).
Please check this blog which provides a very good overview: https://community.sap.com/t5/enterprise-resource-planning-blog-posts-by-sap/intercompany-cost-allocations-in-s-4hana-cloud/ba-p/13442721 

Regarding the questions

1. Cost Allocation Between Company Codes:
- Is it possible to perform cost allocation (assessment/distribution) between different company codes within the same client?
yes
- If yes, which scope item(s) should be activated?
universal allocation (2QL), for compliant reflection please check whether 4AN might be an option to legally reflect the transactions / services exchanged. 
- Which Fiori app(s) should be used?
depends on what is appropriate - refer to list of supported Apps

2. Cost Center Transfer Between Company Codes:
- Is it possible to transfer costs between cost centers in different company codes within the same client?
yes
- If yes, which scope item(s) should be activated?
see above 
- Which Fiori app(s) should be used?
see above 

Kind regards

Thorsten

entry.title: Re: Service Order: Connection between service product and...

entry.title: Re: ALM Test Execution - for multiple testers
entry.content:
Hi,
the only way I could think of is creating 13 test plans and assign the case to a different tester in each plan.

Not knowing your project, I feel like this is somewhat of a niche case, as I usually see each test case being executed only once per test cycle.
Wouldn't executing the same case 13 times be a massive duplication of effort?

Small remark regarding "overwritten": Test results are never "overwritten". You would instead just create a new run for the test case  with each execution. Old runs will still be visible. But as only the youngest run is relevant for reporting this does not solve your problem.

entry.title: How to determine whether the SF OIDC Migration has been successful from the UI of IAS
entry.content:
Since it is a mass run, the failed applications can be identified from the process. However, even if an application is not among the failed ones, it does not necessarily mean there is absolutely no success information. Therefore, this article provides a method for judging from the UI to facilitate the IAS Admin to directly determine whether the migration was successful.

Steps:

1. Go to Applications list:

2. Find your SF applications. The subtitle is like: https://www.successfactors.com/{CompanyId}

3. Check 3 points:

  1. protocol type is: SAML 2.0 & OpenID Connect
  2. Open Id Configuration tile can be found
  3. Client Authentication tile is disabled

 

If all 3 check points have been passed, it indicates that the migration has been successful.

Best regards Henri

entry.title: SAP Partner portal login
entry.content:
How to get help with SAP Partner portal login?


------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Learn more about the SAP Support user and program here.

entry.title: Re: SAP Partner portal login
entry.content:
SAP Partner portal login:

There was a problem with your login.

Access to the SAP Partner Portal requires you to log in using your SAP Universal ID with a linked User ID that has an active partnership status with SAP.
To resolve your access issue:
- Go to SAP Universal ID Account Manager
- Check the User IDs that are listed and click to link them to your SAP Universal ID.
- You can find other User IDs that you may have associated with other e-mail addresses by clicking ‚ÄúAdd accounts‚Äù. Once added, click to link these User IDs to your SAP Universal ID.
- Once a User ID with a partnership association is linked under your SAP Universal ID, select that user when you log into the SAP Partner Portal.

If you do not have any User IDs with a partnership association, but you belong to a company that is an active SAP Partner, you will need to contact the colleagues at your company with the User Administration authorization to create one for you.

For more support visit SAP Partner Portal | welcome

entry.title: Re: What are the best practices for migrating data from legacy CRM systems into SAP CRM or the newer
entry.content: I‚Äôve done a few legacy CRM to SAP CRM/CX migrations, and the key is good prep. Clean and standardize your data first ‚Äî don‚Äôt migrate junk. Define clear field mappings and use a staging environment to test before going live. Leverage SAP tools like Data Workbench or Migration Cockpit, and migrate in small batches so you can fix issues early. Get business users involved for validation and always run reconciliation reports after migration.

entry.title: S/4HANA Cloud Systems Behaviour During Blue-Green Deployment Uptime
entry.content:
What is Blue-Green Deployment?

Blue and Green simply refer to two runtimes on different versions. As shown in the below diagram, Blue is the currently active production runtime, and Green is the updated/upgraded version which would eventually replace the Blue one.

Blue Green Deployment

Blue-Green deployment works like this: the consumer uses the blue runtime; a green runtime is deployed in parallel. Then, the consumers are switched to use the green runtime and the blue runtime is removed.  In above diagram, ‚ÄòPrepare V2‚Äô and ‚ÄòSwitch to V2‚Äô stages represent the Update/Upgrade phase.

As simple as that!

What it means is all the changes in an update/upgrade are deployed without interrupting the user for much duration. After carrying out most of the update/upgrade related tasks in the background, the system simply switches to the updated runtime and the updated system become available. Thus, the downtime experienced by the user, during which logging into system is not allowed, is reduced via Blue-Green deployment.       

Why Blue-Green Deployment?

Blue-Green deployment paves path for zero downtime deployment. This facilitates multiple advantages such as:

  • Continuous business operations since update/upgrade changes are applied without delays
  • Innovations can be deployed more frequently in small increments as business disruption due to downtime is avoided.
  • Risk of change is minimal. In case the update/upgrade fails, it is relatively easier to switch back to previous version and update/upgrade can be re-triggered at later point of time once it is fixed.

What is Downtime and Uptime?

Downtime is the period during the update/upgrade when a business user cannot log into their S/4HANA Cloud system. This is the reason downtimes are considered disruptive.

On the other hand, Blue-Green deployment accomplishes much of its update/upgrade related tasks during Uptime ‚Äì a period during the update/upgrade when a business user is able to login to S/4HANA Cloud system and use certain functionalities that are allowed.

Uptime is restrictive but unlike downtime, is not disruptive. This means that a business user is allowed to log into and perform certain functionalities even when the update/upgrade is going on in background; although with some restrictions in place (more on that in further sections).

For system updates, uptime starts about 12 hours before maintenance period mentioned in 3SL Maintenance Schedule.

What does Uptime allow or restrict?

Logically, the next question to follow is ‚Äì which functionalities are allowed during blue green deployment uptime, and which are blocked.

To maintain consistency across the systems, it is important to put some restrictions around which functionalities are available during blue-green uptime. E.g. - certain system specific functionalities and business transactions including executing existing workflows, maintaining current settings etc. are available during blue-green uptime; whereas other functionalities like release transports, data migration etc. which can affect the consistency across systems are blocked.

Below is the detailed information regarding availability of important functionalities during Blue-Green deployment uptime of a new update/upgrade based on the customer landscape:

Conclusion

Blue-Green deployment helps to safeguard S/4HANA Cloud customers from business disruptions during updates/upgrades. Awareness regarding restrictions in place during Blue-Green uptime will empower customer with clarity about what activities can be continued with even during the updates/upgrades. This would further lead to an overall better experience for S/4HANA Cloud customers.

Glossary

  • Role Creation and Assignments : This refers to role creation via Manage Business Roles app; and role assignment via Manage Business Users app.
  • Workflows and Attachments : This includes creation of new workflows, and execution of existing workflows/attachment functionalities.
  • Transportable Configurations : This refers to those configurations done via CBC Activities (or Implementation Activities app in 3SL) that can be captured in a Transport Request and pushed to further systems. This includes all configurations which are not ‚ÄòCurrent Settings‚Äô.
  • Number Range Current Settings : These are the number range related current settings done in the S/4HANA system.
  • Non-Number Range Current Settings: These are the current settings that are not number-ranges and cannot be captured in a transport request and need to be redone in Production System.
  • Custom Development: This refers to Custom Development that can be done in 3SL systems via ABAP Development Tool.
  • Central Business Configuration (CBC) Project : Access to the projects created in CBC system.
  • Change Project : Creation of a new change project by initiating a change in the project.
  • Add New Country/Scope Extension : This functionality refers to initiating a change in project to add a new country to the scope or additional scope items.
  • Organizational Structure creation and changes : This functionality refers to initiating a change in project to create or edit the organizational structure.
  • Extensibility : In-App and Side-by-Side extensibility done in S/4HANA Cloud.
  • Test Automation Tool : Test Automation Tool is used in S/4HANA Cloud to automate business process testing in the Quality/Test system.
  • Transports :Transport release and import in S/4HANA systems during blue-green deployment uptime.
  • Forms : Forms creation and editing in S/4HANA Output Management in S/4HANA Cloud systems.
  • General Ledger : This refers to any changes made to General Ledger.
  • Data Migration : Data Migration done via Data Migration Cockpit application.

Further Links

In case you are interested to know about Blue-Green Deployment related information and schedules in S/4HANA Cloud, you would find below links useful for further reading:

  • SAP NOTE: https://launchpad.support.sap.com/#/notes/3024158
  • 3SL Maintenance Schedule: https://www.sap.com/documents/2021/09/58ffa59e-f97d-0010-bca6-c68f7e60039b.html 

 

Please feel free to post your questions and comments and you can reach out to Manish Sharma ( co-author -  manish.sharma04@sap.com) or me.

Thanks for reading this blog post. Do like and share the post if you find it useful.

entry.title: Re: Comparison Between BW and Datasphere
entry.content:
Hi, 

depends on the functionality. BW has been around a while.

I would say, when you compare out-of-the-box features (BW) with limited programming set for do-it-on-your-own (DSP). 

BW/4 has limited connections however. BW 7.x used to have DB-Connect, very powerfull, fast and capable, but the BW/4 version no longer supports such connections, whereas DSP includes the PI capabilities with replication (in/outbound) flows. 

Check the BW docu for more details. 

Cheers, Martin

entry.title: Clarification on Client Dependency of Solution Manager‚ÄìBased Custom Code Management
entry.content:
Hi SAP,

Could you please confirm whether Solution Manager‚Äìbased Custom Code Management (CCLM) is client-dependent or client-independent?

We have multiple clients in our production system, and CCLM is currently enabled for client 000.
Do we also need to activate CCLM in all other production clients?

Best regards,
***


------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Learn more about the SAP Support user and program here.

entry.title: Re: Clarification on Client Dependency of Solution Manage...
entry.content:
Dear Customer,

In Solution Manager‚Äìbased Custom Code Management (CCLM), the custom code objects themselves are client-independent, whereas the data maintained or collected is client-dependent.

Since you mentioned that CCLM is already activated in client 000, there is no need to activate it again in other production clients unless you specifically require client-specific data collection or analysis.

Best regards,

SAP CCM Support

entry.title: Explore SAP Localization With the Global Map of Local Versions
entry.content:
In today‚Äôs interconnected world, businesses are growing across borders faster than ever. But with global growth comes local complexity ‚Äî from tax regulations to payroll rules and legal reporting.

Whether you're a consultant, developer, or business user, navigating country-specific requirements and features can be challenging. SAP simplifies this journey with the global map of local versions. This interactive application is your one-stop destination to explore SAP-provided local versions across the globe.

In this short video, you‚Äôll see how to navigate the global map of local versions, apply filters, and explore country-specific upcoming regulatory changes in just a few clicks:

 

Ready to explore SAP‚Äôs localization capabilities?
Visit sap.com/localization and go global with confidence.

 

What is a local version?

A local version is a set of system functionalities tailored to meet the legal, regulatory, and business requirements of a specific country or region. Think tax reports, payroll rules, or legal reporting formats ‚Äî all built into SAP solutions to enable compliance and efficiency.

 

Key features of the global map

1. Comprehensive coverage

Explore over 1000 local versions for countries and regions. The global map of local versions simplifies your localization journey by offering a holistic view of SAP‚Äôs localization portfolio.

2. Search & filter

Easily find what you need by filtering the interactive map:

  • By Product: Filter by SAP S/4HANA Cloud, SAP SuccessFactors, etc.
  • By Country/Region: Select from a list or use the interactive map.
  • By Deployment Type: Cloud, on-premise
  • By Solution Type: SAP, or Partner solution

The map view provides a visual overview, while the list view offers granular details ‚Äî ideal for consultants preparing rollout plans or developers assessing localization gaps.

 

3. Stay ahead of regulatory changes

Direct links to SAP‚Äôs regulatory change manager help you stay informed about upcoming regulations and how they impact your business. These links are prefiltered for you to continue your localization journey and find prospective regulatory changes.

 

4. Find the right SAP Partner

Need additional localization support? Use the SAP-Qualified Partner-Packaged Solution Finder and search for integrated solutions built, sold, and supported by SAP partners that combine SAP software with industry or line-of-business expertise, services, customizations, or applications.

 

5. Deep dive into SAP business solutions

Want to explore further? Use the direct link to the specific SAP product webpage, access dedicated resources and request a demo to expand your SAP landscape.

 

Realize your global potential with SAP

SAP‚Äôs localization capabilities give you the breadth of coverage and depth of expertise to run your business globally ‚Äî while staying locally compliant.

Visit sap.com/localization and take your business global with confidence.

 

Have you used the global map of local versions for your projects? Share your feedback or tips in the comments below.

entry.title: Re: UI element - dropdown attribute modification in Fiori
entry.content:
Hi @sagarbasa_22355 

Hope you're doing well üòä

You can achieve this by navigating to:

MDGIMG > General Settings > Data Quality & Search > Search & Duplicate Check > Create Search View
Here, you can modify the standard views: MDGM_MM_ORGS and MDGM_MM_ORGS_CLF.

If you'd prefer not to alter the standard configurations, you can create a completely custom view and adjust it via:
MDGIMG > General Settings > Data Quality & Search > Define Search Application (select your option) > Allocation of Search Help to Search Applications

Best regards,
Sandeep Suggu.
SAP Master Data Governance

entry.title: Re: Lower of Cost or Market Valuation for In-House Manufa...
entry.content:
Hi @byd,

the inventory valuation methods always run on the individual material level. A relationship to other materials is not considered. For materials which you do not procure externally, the comparison price will be 0, meaning no revaluation does not happen. You can see if any of the other methods are applicable in your situation (such as inventory costing which you would typically use: https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/7f47a6d9441c46ac86c96fd27f6015f0/e149d153c9684608e10000000a174cb4.html?locale=en-US) or you can change material valuation manually (delta or inventory price) after determining the values outside of the system. Keep in mind that you will lose any existing cost component split of the cost estimate if you overwrite the price with a manual one.

Best regards
Marvin

entry.title: SAP Business One Mobile App Configuration & Certificate Hosting Behind Firewall
entry.content:
Dear Experts,

I would really appreciate your guidance on this.

I recently implemented SAP Business One for one of my customers, and they have requested access to the SAP B1 Mobile App. I started the configuration by installing B1if, and the database connection was successfully tested ‚Äî everything worked fine until I reached the step in the SAP documentation that mentions certificate installation.

Here‚Äôs where I‚Äôm stuck:
The IT department has informed me that due to their firewall and security policies, they do not want to expose the SAP server to the public internet. They asked me to come back with a secure hosting approach or alternative method that would allow mobile access without breaching security guidelines.

Can anyone please guide me on:

  1. What exactly are the certificates required at this stage?

  2. How can I host the mobile app service URL securely behind a firewall?

Your insights or real-time examples would be highly appreciated.

Thanks in advance for your time and support!

Best regards,

entry.title: Extending Entitlements for aem-validation-service-plan Across Subaccounts
entry.content:
Hello experts,

We are implementing a CAP service that needs to send and receive events to and from SAP Advanced Event Mesh (AEM). We have followed the configuration steps described in the official SAP documentation:

CAP Plugin for SAP Integration Suite - Advanced Event Mesh

 

In our setup, the CAP service is deployed in a different subaccount from the one where Advanced Event Mesh is provisioned. According to the documentation, the configuration requires a service binding to an instance of SAP Integration Suite (aem-validation-service-plan) to obtain the handshake API endpoint (URI).

However, since the AEM instance exists in a different subaccount, it‚Äôs not possible to directly bind the CAP service to this instance.

We would like to clarify:

 

  1. Whether it is possible to extend the entitlements for the subaccount hosting our CAP application to include the aem-validation-service-plan from Advanced Event Mesh.

  2. If such an extension is possible, would there be any additional cost implications associated with enabling this plan in the CAP application‚Äôs subaccount?

Thank you in advance for your assistance.

Best regards,
Oleksii

entry.content:
–ü—Ä–æ–ø—É—Å—Ç–∏–ª–∏ —Å–∞–º—ñ—Ç –∞–±–æ —Ö–æ—á–µ—Ç–µ –ø–µ—Ä–µ–≥–ª—è–Ω—É—Ç–∏ –Ω–∞–π—Ü—ñ–∫–∞–≤—ñ—à—ñ –º–æ–º–µ–Ω—Ç–∏ —â–µ —Ä–∞–∑?  –ó–∞–ø–∏—Å–∏ —Å–µ—Å—ñ–π —Ç–∞ –ø—Ä–µ–∑–µ–Ω—Ç–∞—Ü—ñ—ó –≤–∂–µ –¥–æ—Å—Ç—É–ø–Ω—ñ ‚Äî —ñ —è —â–∏—Ä–æ —Ä–µ–∫–æ–º–µ–Ω–¥—É—é –æ–∑–Ω–∞–π–æ–º–∏—Ç–∏—Å—è!

–ù–∞–¥–∑–≤–∏—á–∞–π–Ω–æ –∫–æ—Ä–∏—Å–Ω–∏–π –∫–æ–Ω—Ç–µ–Ω—Ç, –æ—Å–æ–±–ª–∏–≤–æ –¥–ª—è —Ç–∏—Ö, —Ö—Ç–æ –ø—Ä–∞—Ü—é—î –∑ –∑–≤—ñ—Ç–Ω—ñ—Å—Ç—é, –µ–ª–µ–∫—Ç—Ä–æ–Ω–Ω–∏–º –¥–æ–∫—É–º–µ–Ω—Ç–æ–æ–±—ñ–≥–æ–º —Ç–∞ –∞–≤—Ç–æ–º–∞—Ç–∏–∑–∞—Ü—ñ—î—é –ø—Ä–æ—Ü–µ—Å—ñ–≤.

 –£ —Ñ–æ–∫—É—Å—ñ ‚Äî –¥–æ—Å–≤—ñ–¥ —Ç–∞–∫–∏—Ö –∫–æ–º–ø–∞–Ω—ñ–π, —è–∫ Nestl√©, SumUp, Crimson Technology Partners —Ç–∞ Roche, —è–∫—ñ –¥—ñ–ª—è—Ç—å—Å—è —Å–≤–æ—ó–º–∏ –ø—ñ–¥—Ö–æ–¥–∞–º–∏ –¥–æ –≤—ñ–¥–ø–æ–≤—ñ–¥–Ω–æ—Å—Ç—ñ –≤–∏–º–æ–≥–∞–º —É —Ä—ñ–∑–Ω–∏—Ö –∫—Ä–∞—ó–Ω–∞—Ö, –≤–∏–∫–æ—Ä–∏—Å—Ç–∞–Ω–Ω—è–º SAP DRC, –∞ —Ç–∞–∫–æ–∂ —Å—Ç—Ä–∞—Ç–µ–≥—ñ—è–º–∏ –∞–≤—Ç–æ–º–∞—Ç–∏–∑–∞—Ü—ñ—ó –Ω–∞ –±–∞–∑—ñ AI.

–ü–µ—Ä–µ–≥–ª—è–Ω—É—Ç–∏ –±–ª–æ–≥ —Ç–∞ –æ—Ç—Ä–∏–º–∞—Ç–∏ –¥–æ—Å—Ç—É–ø –¥–æ –º–∞—Ç–µ—Ä—ñ–∞–ª—ñ–≤: https://url.sap/vyafkb

entry.title: Re: API or function to Reject CR of BP in MDG
entry.content:
Hi @Kevin_zzj ,

Hope you're doing well üòä

Note 01: There are multiple ways to implement this, but here's one possible approach:

Within USMD_SSW_DYNAMIC_AGT_SELECT,
use a combination of Service Name, New Step, and Change Request Type to determine the appropriate values.
Then, append the relevant details ‚Äî User Type, User Value, Agent Group, and Step Type to ct_user_agent_group.

Best regards,
Sandeep Suggu.
SAP Master Data Governance
